data.title: Naval Actions Of The War Of 1812 by Barnes, James: Poor Hardcover (1896)
data.meta_description: Hardcover - Harper & Brothers Publishers, New York - 1896 - Condition: Poor - No Jacket - A Poor copy of a title in which "Mr. Carlton T. Chapman, whose spirited paintings are reproduced to illustrate this volume, has caught the atmosphere of action, and has given us back the old days in a way that makes us feel them." Extensive wear to volume. Navy blue boards have faded gilt decorations on the front, back and spine. Chipping to bottom edge of spine. Tear to spine cloth. Dings, spotting and wear to rear boards. Wear to gilt color top page edgings and deckled page edgings on the other two sides. Previous owner's award notification from Canisius College pasted inside front boards. Previous seller's notes in pencil at top corner of front flyleaf. Sunning to pages. Split along spine inside front boards separating boards from pages. Spotting to pages. "Contents: Preface; Introduction; Chapter 1: The United States frigate "Constitution," on July 17th, 1812, falls in with a British squadron, but escapes, owing to the masterly seamanship of Captain Isaac Hull; Chapter 2: The "Constitution," under command of Captain Hull, captures the British frigate "Guerrie?re,"under the command of Captain Richard Dacres, August 19th, 1812; Chapter 3: The United States sloop of war "Wasp," Captain Jacob Jones, captures the English sloop of war "Frolic" October 18th, 1812: both vessels taken on the same day by the English seventy-four "Poictiers"; Chapter 4: October 25th, 1812, the British frigate "Macedonian," commanded by John S. Carden, is captured by the "United States" frigate, under command of Stephen Decatur: the prize is brought to port; Chapter 5: Captain Wm. Bainbridge, in the "Constitution," captures the British frigate "Java" off the coast of Brazil, December 29th, 1812: the "Jave" is set fire to and blows up; Chapter 6: Gallant action of the privateer schooner "Comet," of 14 guns, against three English vessels and one Portuguese, January 14th, 1813; Chapter 7: The United States sloop of war "Hornet," Captain James Lawrence, takes the British brig "Peacock": the latter sinks after the action,February 24th, 1813; Chapter 8; The United States frigate "Chesapeake" is captured by the Emglish frigate "Shannon" after a gallant defence, June 1st, 1813; Chapter 9: The United States brig "Enterprise," commanded by William Burrows, captures H.B.M. sloop of war "Boxer,"September 5th, 1813: Burrows killed during the action: Chapter 10: On September 10th,1813, the American fleet on Lake Erie, under the command of Oliver Hazard Perry, captures the entire Rnglish naval force under Commodore Barclay; Chapter 11: The American privateer brig "General Armstrong," of 9 guns and 90 men, repulses a boat attack in the harbor of Fayal, the British suffering a terrific loss, September 26th, 1814; Chapter 12: March 28th, 1814, the United States frigate "Essex," under Captain David Porter, is captured by two English vessels, the "Phoebe" and the "Cherub," in the harbor of Valparaiso; Chapter 13: The United States sloop of war"Peacock," commanded by Captain Warrington, takes the British sloop of war "Epervier" on April 29th, 1814; Chapter 14: The United States sloop of war "Wasp," under command of Captain Blakeley, captures the British sloop of war "Reindeer," June 28th,1814. The "Wasp" engages the British sloop of war "Avon" on the 1st of September: the English vessel sinks after the "Wasp" is driven off by a superior force; Chapter 15: September 11th, the American forces on Lake Champlain, under Captain Macdonough, capture the English squadron, under Captain Downey, causing the evacuation of New York State by the British; Chapter 16: The Loss of the "President" [January 15th, 1815]; Chapter 17; The "Constitution," the "Cyane," and the "Levant"; [February 20th, 1815]; Chapter 18 The "Hornet" and the "Penguin" [March 23d, 1815]Chapter 19; The Escape of the "Hornet" [April 29th, 1815]; Index""Description: xiv, 263 pages, 21 unnumbered leaves of plates : illustrations ; 24 cm." - Naval Actions Of The War Of 1812
data.text:
About this Item

A Poor copy of a title in which "Mr. Carlton T. Chapman, whose spirited paintings are reproduced to illustrate this volume, has caught the atmosphere of action, and has given us back the old days in a way that makes us feel them." Extensive wear to volume. Navy blue boards have faded gilt decorations on the front, back and spine. Chipping to bottom edge of spine. Tear to spine cloth. Dings, spotting and wear to rear boards. Wear to gilt color top page edgings and deckled page edgings on the other two sides. Previous owner's award notification from Canisius College pasted inside front boards. Previous seller's notes in pencil at top corner of front flyleaf. Sunning to pages. Split along spine inside front boards separating boards from pages. Spotting to pages. "Contents: Preface; Introduction; Chapter 1: The United States frigate "Constitution," on July 17th, 1812, falls in with a British squadron, but escapes, owing to the masterly seamanship of Captain Isaac Hull; Chapter 2: The "Constitution," under command of Captain Hull, captures the British frigate "Guerrie?re,"under the command of Captain Richard Dacres, August 19th, 1812; Chapter 3: The United States sloop of war "Wasp," Captain Jacob Jones, captures the English sloop of war "Frolic" October 18th, 1812: both vessels taken on the same day by the English seventy-four "Poictiers"; Chapter 4: October 25th, 1812, the British frigate "Macedonian," commanded by John S. Carden, is captured by the "United States" frigate, under command of Stephen Decatur: the prize is brought to port; Chapter 5: Captain Wm. Bainbridge, in the "Constitution," captures the British frigate "Java" off the coast of Brazil, December 29th, 1812: the "Jave" is set fire to and blows up; Chapter 6: Gallant action of the privateer schooner "Comet," of 14 guns, against three English vessels and one Portuguese, January 14th, 1813; Chapter 7: The United States sloop of war "Hornet," Captain James Lawrence, takes the British brig "Peacock": the latter sinks after the action,February 24th, 1813; Chapter 8; The United States frigate "Chesapeake" is captured by the Emglish frigate "Shannon" after a gallant defence, June 1st, 1813; Chapter 9: The United States brig "Enterprise," commanded by William Burrows, captures H.B.M. sloop of war "Boxer,"September 5th, 1813: Burrows killed during the action: Chapter 10: On September 10th,1813, the American fleet on Lake Erie, under the command of Oliver Hazard Perry, captures the entire Rnglish naval force under Commodore Barclay; Chapter 11: The American privateer brig "General Armstrong," of 9 guns and 90 men, repulses a boat attack in the harbor of Fayal, the British suffering a terrific loss, September 26th, 1814; Chapter 12: March 28th, 1814, the United States frigate "Essex," under Captain David Porter, is captured by two English vessels, the "Phoebe" and the "Cherub," in the harbor of Valparaiso; Chapter 13: The United States sloop of war"Peacock," commanded by Captain Warrington, takes the British sloop of war "Epervier" on April 29th, 1814; Chapter 14: The United States sloop of war "Wasp," under command of Captain Blakeley, captures the British sloop of war "Reindeer," June 28th,1814. The "Wasp" engages the British sloop of war "Avon" on the 1st of September: the English vessel sinks after the "Wasp" is driven off by a superior force; Chapter 15: September 11th, the American forces on Lake Champlain, under Captain Macdonough, capture the English squadron, under Captain Downey, causing the evacuation of New York State by the British; Chapter 16: The Loss of the "President" [January 15th, 1815]; Chapter 17; The "Constitution," the "Cyane," and the "Levant"; [February 20th, 1815]; Chapter 18 The "Hornet" and the "Penguin" [March 23d, 1815]Chapter 19; The Escape of the "Hornet" [April 29th, 1815]; Index""Description: xiv, 263 pages, 21 unnumbered leaves of plates : illustrations ; 24 cm.". Seller Inventory # 002869
